title: Is it possible to go to an undergrad college and study in classes like the humanities (philosophy, history, and law), and then go to a business school for an MBA? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer: Definitely yes! Some Background: The MBA and its predecessors were originally developed to provide non-business undergrads with the background to manage a large organization. Thus, a degree in educational administration plus an MBA would seem to be a good combination for a business manager for a school system. A degree such as your humanities degree plus an MBA would provide a good background for managing arts organizations, museums, and other non-profits. The list goes on: Engineering +MBA to run a factory ; MD plus MBA to run a large health care organization. As a non- business major, you may have to take some preparatory courses in such fields, as organizational behavior, accounting, finance, marketing, and management information science to get you up to speed to engage your graduate courses fully. Some MBA Programs have very liberal “waiver” and substitution policies for these preparatory courses, and you would do well to consult with an MBA adviser very early in your program in Humanities. For example, consider taking some courses as part of your Humanities Program that will also meet the prerequisite requirements for the MBA. For example, Advanced Statistics, and an advanced course in Industrial/Organizational Psychology might provide background for the MBA’s required graduate Business Statistics and Organizational Behavior courses. Your college may even have a Minor Program in Business which could help considerably. Talk to your Academic Adviser and an MBA Admissions Adviser. Best of Luck.

Yes — but you would be at a huge disadvantage in the job market. Since the mid-1970’s, most liberal arts degrees, “aren’t worth the paper they’re printed on.” Employers don’t care if you studied philosophy, political science, English, Women’s Studies, etc. With majors like those you will likely be considered “unskilled”. Why would they want to hire a liberal arts + MBA job candidate when they have a pile of resumes from candidates with a relevant undergrad business or tech degree + MBA? Plus, there are two “kinds” of MBA (same degree): Train in business someone with no formal business training. For instance, a nurse (BSN), engineer, computer science major, etc., who wants to get into management in their field.Specialized more broad training for someone who already has a business degree, e.g., someone with an economics degree takes some graduate economics courses applicable to their current economics work plus courses in other business areas such as human resources.In both those cases the MBA holder is building on an existing business-related education. Also, in most such cases the progression is 1) business/tech degree, 2) several years degree-related work experience, 3) MBA that builds on the work experience. But with liberal arts + MBA there would not be either the related undergrad degree or related experience.

The most important things you can carry with you into any graduate school experience are curiosity and sound research skills. You can build them into almost any undergraduate program where you major in a more-or-less traditional discipline. While colleges are offering a number of undergraduate degrees in trendy areas to attract students who attend for “fun,” most of these popular undergraduate majors don’t really lead any place useful. An undergraduate degree in history, political science, or even English, however would be a fine basis on which to build graduate studies in Business. Remember, once you begin graduate school, whatever area you decide to pursue, your work will be single-minded and purposeful, leading towards a degree. In your case, some element of business. It’s there you’ll learn the content and skills to apply in your career, but there won’t be an emphasis on becoming a complete person or emphasizing developing and nurturing a wide variety of interests. But you may have your undergraduate education, all of it, to help you. Keep yourself as broad as you can while meeting the requirements of your advanced education. But be sure to become a lifelong learner.

I think that is a great idea! I don't think there are any prerequisites for a MBA, though a little math may help, but you can pick that up in business school. For example, they had two quantitative analysis tracks in 1973–4 at Rutgers when I got my MBA. I did STEM, so got in the Quant IV and V track; others went into I and II track. I always felt education should have a strong humanities piece to develop the whole person. Grad school tends to be much easier than undergrad, so you should not have a problem. A MBA should help in the work side of education. I had a history minor as an undergrad, and got a humanities degree, and a couple psych masters later, to round me out. I do not believe any of these degrees propelled my career though, which I did not expect anyway. I also think that top business schools would look kindly at a humanities undergrad. But, this is my opinion. Look at both sides of the argument. If you like humanities, that is another factor to bolster your idea.

Most business schools will accept a humanities degree as an entrance to study for an MBA degree, so it is possible to go to an undergrad college and then go to business school for an MBA. I have supervised such students for a business school, and they have tended to do well because the study in the humanities requires a high intellectual level and articulate expression.

Yes, it is possible but you'll have to match your degree to what the school offers. My suggestion is that if you are thinking of doing your MBA, figure out what aspect of business you are interested in pursuing and tailor your undergraduate studies to closely fit that criteria.

Yes, I took a BA in the humanities (philosophy and philosophy) and studied for my MBA at the Tuck and London business schools. Humanities students bring more diversity into the classroom, and into the boardroom.
Yes to can, but best to check the soecific requirements of a given MBA program what else they o they require.
